text:
Jimmy Kimmel's Most Important Moment in His Opening Monologue Wasn't a Joke 
Of course he got to his Matt Damon feud, too. Getty By Matt Miller Feb 26, 2017 After Chris Rock's powerful opening monologue at the Oscars last year, Jimmy Kimmel—hardly Hollywood's most thoughtful comedian—had a lot to live up to. And this year, the world is far more fucked up than it was in 2016. Here we are, watching celebrities dress up pretty and Justin Timberlake dancing around like the country's jester as Democracy crumbles. To Jimmy Kimmel's credit, he didn't ignore what's going on in the world and he still even made it funny. Sure, he addressed his Matt Damon feud and he made fun of Mel Gibson. And He thanked Donald Trump, "Remember last when when it seemed like the Oscars were racist?" Advertisement - Continue Reading Below But his most important moment wasn't even a joke. It was a request: 
There are millions of people watching right now and if every one of you took a minute to reach out to one person you disagree with, someone you like and have a positive, considerate conversation, not as liberals or conservatives, but as Americans, if we would all do that, we would make America great again. We really could. It starts with us.
